Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Grammar across the Curriculum: Workshop at 2017 Linguistic Institute

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
From a linguistic perspective, "grammar" refers to the system of implicit rules that govern the construction of words, phrases and sentences in a language. This award will support a one-day workshop about the teaching of grammar from a descriptive linguistic viewpoint, addressing the challenges, opportunities, and strategies for grammar instruction across the curriculum. Understanding grammatical structure is a central part of understanding human language, and linguistic knowledge is increasingly seen as part of the core knowledge students should acquire as part of their education at the primary, secondary, and higher education levels. The workshop will educate junior scientists and teachers, improving grammar pedagogy, and increasing dialogue about connections between linguistic research and teaching. Furthering linguistic knowledge on the part of the public is additionally important for addressing linguistic prejudice that exists in society; the workshop will include discussion of how dialect variation can be incorporated into grammar courses, as a way of improving understanding about language as one dimension of social diversity. By facilitating collaborative dialogue about the links between linguistic research on grammar and grammar pedagogy, the workshop will simultaneously contribute to linguistics research and teaching concerns. Ultimately, the event will develop an agenda for making grammar pedagogy a more systematic concern, as part of a larger project of increasing attention to the scholarship of teaching and learning in linguistics.

Five invited speakers, all respected scholars and experienced teachers of grammar and related subjects, will address themes related to the teaching and learning of grammar: Attitudes, Goals, Frameworks, or First- Versus Second-Language Study. Each speaker's talk will be followed by ample time for a question-and-answer session, enabling audience members to respond and contribute. Two other sessions will provide opportunities for interaction, exchange, and practical implementation. To address a larger theme of Methods, a methods-sharing session will allow participants the opportunity to present their own teaching tools, assignments, or strategies, and to get feedback on potential strategies. A final roundtable will give participants the opportunity to raise new questions or revisit unanswered ones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop "Grammar across the Curriculum" addressed challenges, opportunities, and strategies for grammar instruction across the curriculum. We engaged in collaborative dialogue about the links between research in linguistic areas related to grammar and grammar pedagogy. The scope of the workshop included grammar instruction occurring under the charge of particular language departments (e.g., English, Spanish, Chinese) and which is therefore focused on developing a linguistic understanding of the morphological and syntactic structure of a particular language. Such courses often carry more applied end-goals, such as teacher education, writing improvement, or foreign language proficiency, but just as often they are simply descriptive in orientation, and are part of a curriculum for language learning or language study. They also carry subsidiary goals of a liberal arts education such as critical thinking skills. The invited speakers mainly addressed issues in higher education grammar instruction, but links were also made to those working in primary and secondary education. One of the main goals of the workshop that was achieved was to gather together professionals interested in fostering greater connections between what is taught as “grammar” across different levels of education and across different content areas.

This workshop met a crucial need within the linguistics teacher-scholar community for greater critical engagement with grammar pedagogy, and the 2017 Linguistic Institute at the University of Kentucky provided the ideal venue for our event. There was clearly an interest within the field for more conversation about grammar instruction, and this interest was reflected in the diversity and participation of the attendees.  

Understanding the structure of languages is a crucial part of understanding language as a human, cultural, cognitive, and biological phenomenon. The workshop made significant impact in helping to educate those who educate future scientists. In addition, we see the teaching of grammar in language departments--typically considered to be part of humanities or liberal arts--as a crucial bridge between scientists and humanists. The critical thinking skills of the liberal arts intersect with scientific hypothesis testing in grammar courses as we teach them, and we were able to make this intersection more explicit among the linguists and language teachers who attended.

We collected and posted Powerpoint/pdf files from the invited speakers for dissemination via our website (https://u.osu.edu/lsa2017grammarworkshop/). The website also includes links to a number of resources that were mentioned by workshop particiapnts during discussion (e.g., corpora, tree-building tools, etc.).

We are currently planning to recruit scholars, including those drawn from those attending the workshop in Lexington, to contribute articles to an edited volume or journal issue on the topic of the role of linguistics in teaching grammar across languages.
